awd_titl_txt: Measurement of Contractility-induced Residual Stress for Tissue Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Tissue engineering and regenerative medicine hold the promise of rebuilding organs for transplants and reconstructing diseased tissues.  A critical challenge for tissue engineering is the ability to design them to mimic mechanical properties of the tissues they replace. Biological cells are not passive but actively alter their surroundings by reaching out, grabbing onto the protein-based scaffold around them and contracting to cause internal stresses. These cell-generated stresses are an important consideration in human health and disease because they alter mechanical and failure behavior of tissues. This study will use an integrated experimental and modeling approach to measure the effect of living cells embedded in engineered tissues as they contract and continuously alter mechanical behavior. The knowledge gained in this project will help predict quality of overall tissue-engineered products, thereby advancing national health, prosperity, and welfare, while promoting the progress of biomechanical sciences. To ensure this research has broader impact, a wide range of outreach and educational activities are planned, e.g., training of K-12 teachers through the Research Experiences for Teachers program, and developing "Explore Research" videos for the public. In addition, the University of Florida Curie Lecture series, which brings in outstanding women scholars to the university, will be supported.

The objective of this research is to monitor mechanical changes in engineered tissues composed of bio-compatible polymeric scaffolds with embedded living cells using innovative high-resolution, in-line techniques.  Stress fields in these tissues will be measured with micro-Raman spectroscopy at one-micron resolution. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy data will be used to develop computational bio-composite models that quantify the contributions of cell contraction to the constitutive response of engineered tissues. This approach of utilizing spectroscopy on engineered tissue surrogates is novel and provides a potentially transformative means for tracking stresses around cells. Consolidated experimental and modeling results will highlight design differences based on gel, cell shape, cell density, and cell contraction with the goal of providing new guidelines for customizing properties of tissues for intended applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Tissue engineering and regenerative medicine hold the promise of rebuilding organs for transplants and reconstructing diseased tissues. A critical issue for growing functional tissue is the requirement of mechanical integrity. For example, tissue engineered blood vessels typically burst under normal physiological pressures, and low mechanical strength hinders clinical translation of many of these constructs. The resulting focus of research has been towards understanding the role of living cells in altering mechanical properties. Biological cells are not passive filler materials. Cells actively alter their surroundings by reaching out, grabbing onto the protein-based scaffold around them and contracting. Cell contraction allows cells to probe mechanical signals and influences critical activities like migration, proliferation, and remodeling. Engineered tissues typically include millions of contracting cells that collectively generate residual stresses.

While an essential feature to the mechanical response, effects of cell contraction on the mechanical deformations are not often measured. As a result, there are few experimentally validated studies linking cell contractions to changes in underlying structural features and mechanical properties. In this study, we investigated the role of live cells in engineered materials, quantifying structural and mechanical changes due to cell contraction on the surrounding matrix with the goal of improving the overall engineered product.

We developed new, high-resolution, in-line tools based on polarized Raman spectroscopy (PRS) that can monitor changes in bulk alignment of structural proteins in scaffolds with the introduction of cells.  While Raman spectroscopy has been used for ceramics, polymers, and whole tissue, its application to structural assessment of tissue engineering scaffolds is novel and provides a means for tracking changes in alignment that alter mechanical response. Furthermore, we have developed computational bio-composite models that quantify the contributions of cell contraction to the constitutive response of engineered tissues. Consolidated experimental and modeling results highlight differences based on tissue type and days of incubation with the goal of providing new guidelines for customizing properties of tissues for intended applications.

Residual stress is one of the principal factors differentiating living tissues that contain contracting cells from non-living tissues that do not contain active cells. Developed PRS techniques provide a new, non-invasive tool for quantifying the structural alignment changes caused by cells on matrix and on the living mechanical response of tissues. Cell-generated deformations are an important consideration because they alter mechanical and failure behavior and improved measurements will allow in-line testing of engineered tissues for manufacture.

To ensure our research has impact beyond our scientific communities, we engaged in a wide range of outreach and educational activities to train the next generation of scientists and engineers. As an integral part of our research approach, we will develop a seminar series titled, Mechanics of Biology: Imaging and Characterization, supported a K12 teacher in our Research Experiences for Teachers program, and trained 2 PhD students and 4 summer REU students. In addition, Dr. Sarntinoranont has continued a Curie Lecture series to bring outstanding women scholars to the University of Florida. The goal of this series is to increase mentorship of women engineering students and provide leadership examples to aspiring faculty.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Malisa Sarntinoranont

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 2. Engineered tissue scaffolds (ETS) at day 2 (A) and day 12 (B) of incubation that were used in PRS alignment studies. (C) Computational models predict stiffening and alignment at molded corner edges. (D) PRS alignment measures in ETS showed increased alignment at the corner edge.
    Maedeh Lotfi
    Public Domain
    Malisa Sarntinoranont
    Tissue alignment studies
  • Figure 1. Overview of high-resolution, in-line tool based on polarized Raman spectroscopy (PRS) that can monitor changes in bulk alignment of structural proteins in engineered tissue scaffolds (ETS)
    Dr. Hui Zhou
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Malisa Sarntinoranont
